0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Cryptorchidism: 4000 units IM 3 times weekly for 3 weeks; OR 5000 units IM every second day for 4 doses; OR 15 injections of 500 to 1000 units IM over a period of 6 weeks; OR 500 units IM 3 times weekly for 4 to 6 weeks and if ineffective, an additional course 1 month later using 1000 units per dose
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, In male patients: 500 to 1000 units IM 3 times weekly for 3 weeks followed by 500 to 1000 units IM 2 times weekly for 3 weeks; OR 4000 units IM 3 times weekly for 6 to 9 months, following which the dosage may be reduced to 2000 units IM 3 times weekly for an additional 3 months
  • Ovulation induction: 5000 to 10,000 units IM 1 day following last dose of menotropins

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and effectiveness not established in children younger than 4 years of age
  • Cryptorchidism: (4 yr and older) 4000 units IM 3 times weekly for 3 weeks; OR 5000 units IM every second day for 4 doses; OR 15 injections of 500 to 1000 units IM over a period of 6 weeks; OR 500 units IM 3 times weekly for 4 to 6 weeks and if ineffective, an additional course 1 month later using 1000 units per dose; therapy is usually started between 4 and 9 years of age
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, In male patients: (4 yr and older) 500 to 1000 units IM 3 times weekly for 3 weeks followed by 500 to 1000 units IM 2 times weekly for 3 weeks; OR 4000 units IM 3 times weekly for 6 to 9 months, following which the dosage may be reduced to 2000 units IM 3 times weekly for an additional 3 months

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• precocious puberty
  • pregnancy; may cause fetal harm (Novarel(R))
  • prostate cancer or other androgen-dependent neoplasm
  • prior allergic reaction to human chorionic gonadotropin

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis has been reported with urinary-derived hCG products
  • arterial thromboembolism has been reported in patients being treated for infertility
  • ascites with or without pain and pleural effusion have been reported in patients being treated for infertility
  • asthma disease; increased risk of fluid retention
  • cardiac disease; increased risk of fluid retention
  • epilepsy disorder; increased risk of fluid retention
  • fluid retention may occur
  • migraine disease; increased risk of fluid retention
  • multiple births have been reported in patients being treated for infertility
  • neonates and infants; diluent contains benzyl alcohol
  • ovarian cysts, enlargement or rupture, resulting in hemoperitoneum, has been reported in patients being treated for infertility
  • ovarian hyperstimulation, a syndrome of sudden ovarian enlargement, has been reported in patients being treated for infertility
  • pediatric patients; precocious puberty may develop in children treated for cryptorchidism; discontinue use if signs and symptoms of precocious puberty occur
  • renal disease; increased risk of fluid retention

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain
  • Endocrine metabolic:Gynecomastia, Precocious puberty
  • Neurologic:Headache
  • Psychiatric:Depression, Irritability, Restlessness
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Arterial thromboembolism
  • Hepatic:Ascites
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Reproductive:Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
  • Respiratory:Pleural effusion

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) is a polypeptide hormone which contains an alpha sub-unit that is similar to the alpha components of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and a beta sub-unit that has a different amino acid sequence. HCG exerts nearly identical effects as LH in activating the production of gonadal steroid hormones to produce androgens and progesterone and in influencing the development of male secondary sex characteristics and in normal menstrual cycle, but it has a weak FSH activity. It sustains the corpus luteum during pregnancy, causing it to secrete estrogen and progesterone.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intramuscular
  • for IM use only
  • (Novarel(R)) reconstitute with bacteriostatic water for injection; reconstituted solution stable for 30 days when refrigerated; refrigerate reconstituted at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F)
  • (generic version) reconstitute with bacteriostatic water for injection; reconstituted solution stable for 60 days when refrigerated

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• serum progesterone, luteinizing hormone
  • estradiol levels
  • ovarian ultrasound day 7 and 14 (ovarian enlargement, ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome)
  • onset of ovulation
  • routine pelvic exam
  • cryptorchidism: signs of precocious puberty

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    Intramuscular Powder for Solution: 10000 U
  • Novarel
    Intramuscular Powder for Solution: 10000 U
  • Pregnyl
    Intramuscular Powder for Solution: 10000 U

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: This drug may cause gynecomastia, precocious puberty, thromboembolic disorder, headache, or irritability.
